questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ulcerative colitis Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that causes chronic inflammation in the colonic mucosa. One of the characteristic features of UC is the formation of pseudopolyps, which are raised areas of mucosal tissue that occur as a result of regenerative epithelial growth after ulceration. These pseudopolyps are considered a reparative response to the chronic ulceration and inflammation seen in UC. Unlike true polyps, pseudopolyps do not have a stalk and are not neoplastic. They are a distinctive feature seen on colonoscopy in patients with ulcerative colitis. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Crohn’s disease Crohn’s disease is another form of inflammatory bowel disease that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, including the small intestine. While Crohn’s disease can cause ulcerations, it is not typically associated with pseudopolyps. Crohn's disease often results in transmural inflammation (involving all layers of the bowel wall) and can cause fistulas and strictures, rather than pseudopolyps. The ulcerations in Crohn's are often deeper and irregular, and pseudopolyps are less commonly seen. C. Celiac sprue Celiac sprue (or celiac disease) is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten in genetically susceptible individuals. It primarily affects the small intestine, causing villus atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lymphocytic infiltration, but it does not typically form pseudopolyps. The main findings in celiac disease are intestinal damage and malabsorption, rather than the mucosal changes that lead to pseudopolyp formation. D. Whipple’s disease Whipple’s disease is a rare bacterial infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It can affect multiple organs, including the small intestine, but the hallmark of the disease is the infiltration of macrophages containing foamy material within the intestinal mucosa, rather than the formation of pseudopolyps. Whipple’s disease can cause malabsorption and diarrhea, but pseudopolyps are not a characteristic feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is MOST commonly affected by ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rectum Ulcerative colitis (UC) is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that primarily affects the colon and is characterized by continuous inflammation starting from the rectum and extending proximally in a continuous fashion. The rectum is almost always involved in UC, and it is typically the most affected segment of the colon. In fact, proctitis (inflammation of the rectum) is often the first manifestation of the disease. The inflammation in UC tends to progress proximally in a continuous manner, involving the sigmoid colon, then the descending colon, and potentially the entire colon in more severe cases. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Cecum The cecum may be affected in UC, especially in more severe forms or when the disease progresses proximally, but it is not the most commonly affected area. While ulcerative colitis can eventually involve the cecum, it typically begins in the rectum and moves upward in the colon. The cecum is less commonly involved in early stages. C. Sigmoid colon The sigmoid colon is frequently involved in ulcerative colitis, particularly as the disease progresses beyond the rectum. However, the rectum is typically affected first and most severely. The sigmoid colon is often involved as part of the progression of the disease, but it is not the most commonly affected region, which is the rectum. D. Terminal ileum The terminal ileum is typically not affected in ulcerative colitis. Ulcerative colitis primarily involves the colon, whereas Crohn’s disease, another form of inflammatory bowel disease, commonly affects the terminal ileum. UC usually spares the small intestine, with the exception of isolated cases where the disease may extend into the proximal colon and occasionally cause backwash ileitis (inflammation of the terminal ileum), but this is not typical.

Correct Answer (A) Ulcerative Colitis Backwash ileitis refers to the inflammation of the terminal ileum, which is typically seen in ulcerative colitis (UC), especially in cases where the disease is severe and involves the proximal colon. This condition occurs as a result of the retrograde extension of inflammation from the colon into the ileum, which is commonly seen in pan-colitis or extensive UC. It is called "backwash" because the inflammation in the colon "washes back" into the terminal ileum. However, backwash ileitis is not a hallmark feature of ulcerative colitis and is seen only in a subset of patients with extensive colonic involvement. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. Crohn’s Disease Crohn’s disease is characterized by transmural inflammation and can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, including the terminal ileum, which is commonly involved. However, Crohn's disease typically causes discontinuous or skip lesions with fistulas and strictures, rather than the continuous colonic inflammation seen in ulcerative colitis. Backwash ileitis is not a feature of Crohn’s disease. C. Colonic Carcinoma Colonic carcinoma (colon cancer) does not cause backwash ileitis. Cancer in the colon may cause obstruction, bleeding, or weight loss, but it does not lead to the inflammation of the terminal ileum characteristic of backwash ileitis. It is not associated with ulcerative colitis-like changes in the ileum. D. Ileal Polyp An ileal polyp is a benign growth in the ileum, but it does not lead to backwash ileitis. Polyps in the ileum are typically not associated with widespread inflammation of the terminal ileum or colon. Therefore, this option is unrelated to backwash ileitis.

questions.text: A 41-years-old male patient presented with recurrent episodes of bloody Diarrhea &mucus for 5 years. Despite regular treatment with adequate doses of sulfasalazine, he has had several exacerbations of his disease and required several weeks of steroids for the control for flares. What should be the next line of treatment for him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Azathioprine This patient has been suffering from recurrent episodes of bloody diarrhea and mucus, and although he has been treated with sulfasalazine (a 5-aminosalicylic acid derivative) and corticosteroids for flare-ups, he continues to experience frequent exacerbations of his disease. This suggests moderate to severe ulcerative colitis (UC) that requires immunosuppressive therapy to maintain long-term remission and reduce dependency on steroids. In this case, the most appropriate next line of treatment is azathioprine, an immunosuppressant that is commonly used to manage steroid-dependent or steroid-refractory UC. Azathioprine works by inhibiting purine synthesis, which in turn reduces the activity of T lymphocytes, leading to immune suppression and reduction of inflammation. It is often used for long-term management and can help reduce flare-ups and the need for steroids. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Methotrexate Methotrexate is an immunosuppressive drug often used in the treatment of Crohn’s disease and certain autoimmune conditions, but it is not typically used as a first-line therapy in ulcerative colitis. While it may be considered in patients who fail other therapies or have specific indications, it is less effective than azathioprine for managing steroid dependence in UC. C. Cyclosporine Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that is used for severe, acute exacerbations of UC that do not respond to steroids. It is typically reserved for severe, refractory cases or for patients with toxic megacolon. However, cyclosporine is not typically used for long-term management of UC and has significant side effects, so it is not the most appropriate option in this scenario. D. Cyclophosphamide Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent with immunosuppressive properties and is used in severe autoimmune diseases, but it is not commonly used in the treatment of ulcerative colitis. Cyclophosphamide is typically reserved for conditions that are resistant to other therapies or for life-threatening diseases, due to its potential for severe side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is MOST commonly affected by Crohn’s Disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Terminal ileum Crohn's disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that can affect any part of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, but the most commonly affected area is the terminal ileum, which is the last part of the small intestine before it joins the large intestine. The terminal ileum is involved in approximately 40-50% of cases of Crohn's disease, and this region often shows skip lesions (patchy areas of inflammation), which is characteristic of Crohn's disease. The inflammation typically extends into the transmural layers of the bowel wall and can lead to complications like strictures, fistulas, and abscesses. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Cecum Although the cecum (the beginning of the large intestine) can be affected by Crohn's disease, it is less commonly involved compared to the terminal ileum. Crohn's disease often has a predilection for the small intestine, particularly the terminal ileum, and the cecum is involved in a smaller proportion of cases. When the cecum is affected, it is usually part of a more extensive disease process. B. Rectum The rectum is most commonly affected in ulcerative colitis (another form of IBD) rather than Crohn's disease. While Crohn's disease can affect the rectum in some cases (especially if it extends into the colon), it is less common for it to involve the rectum as frequently as ulcerative colitis. The rectum in Crohn's disease is typically involved only in extensive cases, and the disease often spares the rectum in isolated small bowel disease. C. Sigmoid colon The sigmoid colon (the S-shaped portion of the colon near the rectum) can be affected in Crohn's disease, but it is less common than the terminal ileum. When the sigmoid colon is involved, it is often part of a broader colonic involvement. Crohn's disease tends to cause patchy inflammation and skip lesions, and while the sigmoid colon may be affected, it is not as typical as the terminal ileum for initial presentation.

questions.text: The presence of anti-Saccharomyces cerevisae antibody is a surrogate marker of one of the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Crohn’s disease The presence of anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA) is considered a surrogate marker for Crohn's disease, a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). ASCA is an antibody against a yeast component, and its levels are found to be elevated in individuals with Crohn's disease, particularly in those with small bowel involvement. ASCA is used as a serological marker in diagnosing Crohn's disease, helping to differentiate it from ulcerative colitis, another form of IBD, which does not show elevated ASCA levels. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Celiac disease Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by the ingestion of gluten in genetically predisposed individuals. It involves the small intestine, but the anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody (ASCA) is not a marker of celiac disease. The serological markers for celiac disease are anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies and anti-endomysial antibodies, not ASCA. C. Ulcerative colitis Ulcerative colitis is another form of IBD that primarily affects the colon and rectum. While it shares some symptoms with Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis typically does not show an elevated ASCA level. Instead, p-ANCA (perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies) are more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. ASCA is more specific to Crohn’s disease and is usually negative or low in patients with ulcerative colitis. D. Tropical sprue Tropical sprue is an acquired condition often seen in tropical regions, characterized by malabsorption of nutrients and associated with intestinal inflammation. It does not involve the production of anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibodies (ASCA), making it an incorrect answer. The diagnosis of tropical sprue is typically made through clinical features, intestinal biopsy, and response to antibiotics, rather than serological markers like ASCA.

questions.text: Extraintestinal manifestations of Inflammatory bowel disease include all of the following, Except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Osteoarthritis Osteoarthritis is not considered an extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). While osteoarthritis is a common joint condition that may occur in the general population, it is not typically associated with IBD. Inflammatory arthritis, such as spondyloarthropathy or enteropathic arthritis, is a well-known extraintestinal manifestation of IBD, but osteoarthritis does not have the same inflammatory characteristics and is not directly linked to the autoimmune processes involved in IBD. Why the Other Options Are Correct: A. Uveitis Uveitis is an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD, commonly associated with both Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. Uveitis refers to inflammation of the uveal tract (the middle layer of the eye), and it can lead to symptoms like eye pain, redness, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light. It is considered a significant complication of IBD and requires prompt treatment. B. Sclerosing cholangitis Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation and scarring of the bile ducts, leading to liver damage. It is closely linked with ulcerative colitis, in particular, and is considered one of the extraintestinal manifestations of IBD. Patients with PSC and ulcerative colitis may also have an increased risk of liver cancer. D. Skin nodules Skin nodules, such as erythema nodosum and pyoderma gangrenosum, are common cutaneous manifestations of IBD. Erythema nodosum presents as painful red nodules typically on the shins, and pyoderma gangrenosum is characterized by large, ulcerating skin lesions. Both are considered extraintestinal manifestations of IBD, often linked to disease flares.

questions.text: Antibody shown to be useful for Crohn’s Disease is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Natalizumab Natalizumab is an monoclonal antibody that is useful for Crohn’s disease, particularly for patients with moderate to severe disease who do not respond adequately to other treatments. It works by inhibiting the adhesion of immune cells (specifically T lymphocytes) to the endothelial cells, which prevents the immune cells from migrating into the intestines and causing inflammation. Natalizumab is often used when other biologic therapies or immunosuppressive treatments are ineffective. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Omalizumab Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody used primarily to treat allergic asthma and chronic spontaneous urticaria. It works by binding to IgE, which prevents it from interacting with the high-affinity IgE receptor on mast cells and basophils, thus inhibiting allergic responses. Omalizumab is not used in Crohn’s disease or other inflammatory bowel diseases. B. Palivizumab Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody used to prevent serious respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections in infants and young children at high risk. It works by binding to the RSV fusion protein and preventing the virus from entering host cells. Palivizumab is not relevant to Crohn’s disease or other gastrointestinal conditions. D. None of the above This option is incorrect because Natalizumab (Option C) is indeed a valid monoclonal antibody treatment for Crohn’s disease, making Option D incorrect.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions commonly predisposes to colonic carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ulcerative colitis. Correct Response: A. Ulcerative colitis: Long-standing ulcerative colitis is a well-known risk factor for the development of colonic carcinoma. Chronic inflammation in the colon over time leads to dysplasia, which can progress to carcinoma. The risk increases with the duration of the disease (especially after 8-10 years), the extent of colonic involvement (pancolitis is associated with higher risk), and the presence of other factors such as primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). Routine colonoscopic surveillance with biopsy is recommended in patients with extensive or long-standing ulcerative colitis to detect precancerous changes early. Explanation of Incorrect Options: B. Crohn’s disease: Although Crohn's disease involves chronic inflammation and can affect the colon, it has a lower risk of progression to colonic carcinoma compared to ulcerative colitis. The risk increases only in long-standing cases with extensive colonic involvement, but it is less common overall compared to ulcerative colitis. C. Diverticular disease: Diverticular disease is associated with inflammation (diverticulitis) or complications such as perforation, but it is not a predisposing factor for colonic carcinoma. The structural changes in the colon are non-neoplastic and unrelated to cancer development. D. Ischemic colitis: Ischemic colitis results from reduced blood flow to the colon, leading to temporary inflammation and ulceration. It is not associated with an increased risk of colonic carcinoma as the damage is usually acute and does not involve chronic inflammation or dysplasia.

questions.text: A 27 -year old female presents with complaints of fever, arthritis and painful nodules on the shins associated with bloody diarrhea. She is most likely to be suffering from: (UPSC 2001)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ulcerative colitis Explanation for Correct Answer: The most likely diagnosis for a 27-year-old female presenting with fever, arthritis, painful nodules on the shins, and bloody diarrhea is Ulcerative colitis (UC), which is an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Ulcerative colitis often presents with bloody diarrhea and is frequently associated with extra-intestinal manifestations such as arthritis (a common complication), erythema nodosum (painful nodules on the shins), and systemic symptoms like fever. This combination of symptoms makes Ulcerative colitis the most fitting diagnosis. Explanation of Incorrect Responses: A. Amoebic dysentery: Amoebic dysentery caused by Entamoeba histolytica typically leads to bloody diarrhea, but it is not usually associated with arthritis or erythema nodosum (painful shin nodules). The systemic symptoms in amoebic dysentery are often limited to gastrointestinal symptoms and occasional liver abscess, rather than the broader systemic signs seen in Ulcerative colitis. B. Tropical sprue: Tropical sprue is an illness associated with malabsorption and diarrhea, but it does not typically cause bloody diarrhea, arthritis, or erythema nodosum. The classic presentation involves chronic diarrhea and nutritional deficiencies, but there are no prominent extra-intestinal manifestations like arthritis or skin nodules. C. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome is characterized by hemolytic anemia, acute kidney failure, and thrombocytopenia. It is typically caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli infections and is not commonly associated with arthritis or painful nodules on the shins. HUS can cause bloody diarrhea, but the overall presentation is different from that of Ulcerative colitis.

choices.text: Bleeding distal to junction to proximal. 1/3rd and distal 2/3rd of transverse colon
Bleeding distal to junction of proximal 2/3rd and distal 1/3rd of transverse colon
Bleeding from large bowel beyond ileocaecaI junction
Bleeding from small bowel from beyond ligament of Treitz

questions.text: Lower gastoinestinal bleeding is defined as: (UPSC 20(04)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bleeding from large bowel beyond ileocaecal junction Explanation for Correct Answer: Lower gastrointestinal bleeding refers to any bleeding that originates from the large bowel (colon, rectum) or small bowel beyond the ileocaecal junction. This includes bleeding from the cecum, ascending colon, transverse colon, descending colon, rectum, and anus. The ileocaecal junction is the demarcation point between the small bowel and the large bowel, so bleeding beyond this point is considered lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Explanation of Incorrect Responses: A. Bleeding distal to junction of proximal 1/3rd and distal 2/3rd of transverse colon: This description refers to a location within the transverse colon, which is part of the large bowel, but it does not define lower gastrointestinal bleeding as it specifies a section of the colon rather than being specific to the small bowel or beyond the ileocaecal junction. B. Bleeding distal to junction of proximal 2/3rd and distal 1/3rd of transverse colon: Similar to option A, this describes a segment of the transverse colon. While this is still lower gastrointestinal bleeding, it does not include the important reference point of the ileocaecal junction, which is key in differentiating between upper and lower GI bleeding. D. Bleeding from small bowel from beyond ligament of Treitz: This describes upper gastrointestinal bleeding, not lower. The ligament of Treitz marks the junction between the duodenum (which is part of the upper gastrointestinal tract) and the jejunum. Bleeding beyond this point would still be classified as upper gastrointestinal bleeding, not lower.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with symptoms of frequent bowel movements, crampy abdominal pain, and the passage of mucus. There is no history of any bloody diarrhea, but recently, he developed joint discomfort in his hands, knees, and back. On examination he is thin, and his abdomen is soft with voluntary guarding in the left lower quadrant. His joints are not actively inflamed and there is an asymmetric distribution. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ulcerative colitis The patient presents with frequent bowel movements, crampy abdominal pain, and the passage of mucus, which are characteristic symptoms of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), specifically ulcerative colitis (UC). UC typically affects the colon and is often associated with mucus discharge, abdominal pain, and frequent bowel movements. The absence of bloody diarrhea does not rule out UC, as it can sometimes present without visible blood. The additional joint discomfort (in the hands, knees, and back) is a known extra-intestinal manifestation of UC, often seen in the form of spondyloarthropathy, which is an asymmetric form of arthritis commonly seen in UC. The left lower quadrant tenderness also fits with the typical distribution of UC, which often affects the distal colon. Why the Other Options are Incorrect: A. Lymphoma of the bowel Lymphoma of the bowel is a rare condition that may present with symptoms like abdominal pain, weight loss, and changes in bowel habits, but it would be less likely to cause the chronic, relapsing symptoms (especially with mucus and joint discomfort) seen in this patient. Lymphoma typically presents with more systemic signs, such as fever, night sweats, and weight loss, and would not typically cause mucus discharge as a primary symptom. Additionally, lymphoma is unlikely to cause joint pain in the absence of other systemic symptoms. B. Amyloid infiltration Amyloid infiltration of the gastrointestinal tract can cause symptoms like diarrhea or weight loss, but it is not a typical cause of mucus passage or frequent bowel movements as seen in this patient. Moreover, amyloidosis would more likely present with other systemic symptoms such as edema, fatigue, and organ dysfunction (e.g., renal involvement) rather than isolated gastrointestinal and joint symptoms. The joint symptoms described (in the hands, knees, and back) are more consistent with an inflammatory condition like UC. C. Chronic pancreatitis Chronic pancreatitis could cause abdominal pain and digestive disturbances, but it would not typically present with mucus in the stool or the frequent bowel movements seen here. Pancreatitis is usually associated with epigastric pain, nausea, and steatorrhea, but mucus discharge is not a hallmark of this condition. Additionally, joint pain is not a typical feature of pancreatitis, and this patient’s symptom pattern is more consistent with an inflammatory bowel condition like ulcerative colitis.

choices.text: In the stenotic or non-stenotic phase of the disease

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with chronic diarrhea associated with pain abdomen. Sometimes it is associated with blood in stools. He also complaints of joint pains and red painful nodules on shin area. On examination erythema nodosum present. Blood test showed ASCA positivity. Barium enema is done which showed “string sign” in the ileal area. In which of the following conditions is this sign most often seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In the stenotic or non-stenotic phase of the disease The "string sign" seen on a barium enema is characteristic of Crohn's disease, particularly in the ileal area. This sign represents the appearance of a narrowed or stenotic segment of the bowel, where contrast medium flows through a very tight opening, creating a thin, string-like appearance. It can occur during both the stenotic phase (when inflammation causes narrowing and fibrosis) and the non-stenotic phase (when the bowel wall is inflamed but not yet narrowed). In this case, the presence of ASCA (Anti-Saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody) positivity, chronic diarrhea, painful abdomen, blood in stools, and joint pain (with associated erythema nodosum) points towards Crohn’s disease, making the "string sign" a likely finding. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: B. In the stenotic phase only The "string sign" is most commonly associated with stenosis due to fibrosis and inflammation in Crohn's disease. However, it can also be seen in the non-stenotic phase, where bowel inflammation leads to a narrowing that may not be as severe. So, while the string sign is often seen in the stenotic phase, it is not exclusive to it and can also be present in the non-stenotic phase of the disease. C. With rectal involvement While Crohn's disease can involve the rectum, the "string sign" is most often observed in the ileal area, particularly in the small intestine. Rectal involvement in Crohn's disease typically manifests as perianal disease or inflammation near the anal canal, but it is not usually associated with the classic "string sign" seen in the small bowel. D. With gastric involvement Gastric involvement in Crohn's disease is rare, and the "string sign" is not typically seen in the stomach. The string sign is more commonly observed in the ileum, where the disease often causes inflammation and stenosis. Therefore, the presence of a string sign is not associated with gastric involvement.
